conclusion: Objects A and B move through the air and are placed down at the location of objects C, D, E, F, coming into contact with them due to gravity.
All four upright blocks (C, D, E, F) will be knocked over and end up lying on the table once the large panels (A and B) are set down.
A and B move downward until their lower faces touch the tops of the blocks beneath them.
The downward motion continues (either from the weight of the panels or the hand placing them), so a vertical force is applied to the blocks.
Because the blocks are tall and narrow, the contact point is above their centres of mass; a small horizontal mismatch or any slight tilt of A or B produces a tipping moment.
Each block starts to rotate about its lower edge.
C and D tip outward from the left panel.
E and F tip outward from the right panel.
Gravity pulls the partly-rotated blocks past the point of no return; they fall flat.
A and B come to rest on the table surface, while C, D, E, F lie toppled nearby.
